entry.title: CX_DBA_PARSE_ERROR in DBACOCKPIT Dump History - ASE 16.0.04.07 on SAP Kernel 754
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am encountering a dump in DBACOCKPIT when trying to access Backup and Recovery -> Database Dump History.

Error Details:

  • Exception: CX_DBA_PARSE_ERROR

  • Class: CL_SYB_DBMS_UTILS

  • Method: CAST_FMT_TSTAMP_TO_DB6TSTAMP

  • Message: Unable to parse date/time.

System Environment:

  • SAP Kernel: 754 Patch 628 (64-bit Unicode)

  • DB Client Library: Sybase ASE 16.0.04.07

  • OS: SLES 15

What I have checked so far:

  1. OS Locales: The environment variables for sidadm and sybsid are set to en_US.UTF-8.

     

  2. https://me.sap.com/notes/2780872/E: I found this Note which describes the exact issue, but it only references older SAP Notes (for Basis 7.40) and does not provide specific correction instructions for Basis 754.

  3. Note 1558958: This collection note also seems to target older releases.

It seems like the ABAP parser cannot handle the date/time format returned by the ASE 16.0.04.07 engine.

Does anyone know the specific Correction Collection Note for SAP_BASIS 754 that addresses this timestamp parsing issue? Or is there a specific DB parameter/locale setting within ASE that could force a compatible date format?

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: LGM Knowledge Snippet: The idea behind Normalized Quantities
entry.content:
How do you compare 100 pieces of Product A with 50 boxes of Product B? How do you know when you've consolidated enough cargo to fill a truck? This is where Normalized Quantities come into play in SAP Logistics Management - a concept designed to represent estimated pallet footprints for meaningful consolidation decisions.

The Pallet Footprint Problem

In transportation planning, the key question is: "How much truck space does this cargo need?" The answer isn't in pieces, boxes, or kilograms - it's in how many pallet positions the cargo occupies on the truck floor.

Think about it: A truck driver doesn't care if you have 1,000 units or 10,000 units. They care about: "How many pallet spots does this take up on my truck?"

That's exactly what normalized quantities represent in LGM: the pallet footprint of your cargo.

The Geographic Challenge: Not All Pallets Are Equal

Here's where it gets interesting. When we say "pallet footprint," which pallet are we talking about?

Euro-Pallet vs. US Pallet: A Real World Problem

In Europe, one of the most common standard for pallets is the Euro-pallet:

  • Dimensions: 1200mm × 800mm (0.96 m²)
  • Standard truck capacity: 20-24 Euro-pallet positions
  • used Unit of Measure Code: EPA (for the example here, this is not a delivered content)

In the United States, it's the US pallet:

  • Dimensions: 48" × 40" (1.94 m² - double the Euro-pallet!)
  • Standard 53-foot trailer: 26-28 US pallet positions
  • used Unit of Measure Code: UPA (for the example here, this is not a delivered content)

Let's say you're shipping 1,200 units of Product X from two different warehouses:

Frankfurt Warehouse:
  • Product X: 120 units fit on 1 Euro-pallet
  • Normalized quantity: 1,200 ÷ 120 = 10 EPA
  • Truck capacity used: 10/24 = ~42% of a European truck
Chicago Warehouse:
  • Product X: 280 units fit on 1 US pallet (larger footprint!)
  • Normalized quantity: 1,200 ÷ 280 = 4.3 UPA
  • Truck capacity used: 4.3/26 = ~17% of an American truck

Same product, same quantity, but completely different truck capacity requirements. This is why normalized quantities must be geography-specific - they represent actual physical footprint on region-specific trucks.

The key insight: Normalized quantities represent the regional standard pallet format for measuring truck/container capacity.

How SAP Logistics Management Implements This

Step 1: Determine the Regional Pallet Standard

When a Transportation Request is created, a business rule(NORMALIZED_UNIT_OF_MEASURE_DETERMINATION) determines which pallet format represents capacity for that geography:

IF Shipping Point DE01 → Normalized UoM = 'EPA' (Euro-pallet positions) IFShipping Point US02  → Normalized UoM = 'UPA' (US pallet positions) 

Step 2: Convert Everything to Pallet Equivalents

The system converts each item to pallet positions using product-specific conversion factors:

  • "200 pieces of Product A = 1 EPA position"
  • "4 cartons of Product B = 1 EPA position"
  • "2 boxes of Product C = 0.5 EPA position"

Step 3: Aggregate for Truck Capacity Decisions

All items are summed to show total pallet positions needed:

  • Transportation Request level: Sum of all item pallet positions
  • Consignment level: Sum of all assigned Transportation Requests

This aggregated number directly answers: "How many pallet positions do I need on the truck?"

On a note: At the moment we only do this aggregation if the normalized quantity can be determined for all items. This might become configurable in future.

Practical Example: Hamburg Distribution Center

You're consolidating LTL shipments from Hamburg. Your consolidation rule: "Ship when you reach 15 EPA pallet positions OR 12:00 noon, whichever comes first."

Throughout the morning, different products arrive:

Time Product Original Quantity Pallet Positions
9:00 AMIndustrial components480 pieces2.4 EPA
9:30 AMPackaged goods12 cartons3.0 EPA
10:15 AMBulk items84 boxes4.2 EPA
11:00 AMPre-palletized goods6 Euro-pallets6.0 EPA

Total: 15.6 EPA pallet positions ✅

The system triggers consolidation cutoff. You know exactly what you need: a truck with ~16 pallet positions, which is perfect for a standard European LTL carrier (they typically quote 15-20 pallet bands).

Behind the scenes, you're shipping "480 pieces + 12 cartons + 84 boxes + 6 pallets" - an impossible mental calculation. But normalized to pallet positions, it's clear: 15.6 EPA pallet spots.

Why This Matters

The normalized quantity concept solves several critical problems:

  1. Consolidation Decisions: "Do I have enough cargo?" translates to "Do I have enough pallet positions?"This helps e.g. to determine the correct processing variant ( the respective input parameter is planned to be added for the processing variant determination)
  2. Carrier Determination: The best carrier can depend on the number of pallets you expect to ship.
  3. Carrier Communication: German carriers expect "15 EPA pallet positions." US carriers expect "5 UPA pallet positions." The system speaks their language.

Closing Thoughts

Normalized quantities translate the complex world of mixed products, different units of measure, and varied packaging into one simple question: "How many pallet positions does this cargo occupy?"

By using region-specific pallet standards (EPA in Frankfurt, UPA in Chicago, AUS in Sydney), LGM ensures that consolidation decisions reflect actual truck capacity requirements in each market.

The next time you see "15.6 EPA" on a consignment, remember: that's not just a number - it's telling you that you need 15-16 Euro-pallet positions on a European truck. It's the difference between guessing truck capacity and knowing exactly what you need.

And if you're wondering why 1,200 units converts to 10 pallets in Europe but only 4.3 pallets in the US? Now you know - a US pallet has literally double the footprint of a Euro-pallet, so fewer are needed to represent the same cargo.

Feel free to leave comments if you have questions about how normalized quantities work in your specific scenarios!

entry.title: Reference field in Cloud for Credit Integration - Manage Credit Reports
entry.content:
Hello,

we are facing an issue with the Reference Field in the “Manage Credit Reports” app in SAP S/4HANA Cloud for credit integration (Foundry) 

Normally, when we order a credit report, the Reference Field is automatically populated with the Business Partner ID. After the credit report is received, the Reference Field in the Manage Credit Reports app remains populated, and we can also see which user ordered the report.

However, when Business Partner Monitoring is active, the Reference Field is not populated when a credit report is updated. In addition, the Creator is shown as anonymous. Unfortunately, our business department relies on this information to quickly identify the relevant Business Partner when reviewing the Manage Credit Reports app.

After discussing this with our credit agency, we learned that they are not able to populate the Reference Field on their side.

Do you have any suggestions on how the Reference Field could be populated in this scenario?
Is there, for example, a way to enhance or inject custom logic so that the Reference Field in Cloud for Credit Integration is populated (e.g. based on the Company Name or Business Partner)?

Thank you !

entry.title: S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 Fully-Activated Appliance standard installation
entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for hostname change and SID change. Also if you want to change instance number the command, screens show where you can change the instance number. This would make sense if your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID. Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

If you want to do standard installation with no change in hostname and sid please refer to other blog In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily.

This blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2025 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2025 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51059242_1 to 51059242_5  files and SWPM20SP22_5-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51059242_5, SWPM10SP45_4-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

TIP: The /sapmedia filesystem could be external mount. To save this space, the files could be downloaded to /hana/data/HDB and deleted as they are being extracted. In this case it would be good to extract dbdata files first.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51059242_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51059242_1 to 51059242_4) to /sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51059242_2/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_3/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_4/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-*   .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia/# cd 51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1

cat dblog.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H

Then extract the files:
sid-hdb-s4h:/usr/sap #cd 51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_1
cat usrsap_s4h.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner  -zpxvf - -C /
cat sapmnt_s4h.tgz-* | tar --numeric-owner  -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS  
Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51059242_1/SAPS4HANA2025SAPHANADB20_5/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml


Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE 

Please ensure groupid=1000 is free and groupid=79 are free. Use SAP Note 3686516 for troubleshooting.

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

sid-hdb-s4h: ##/hana/shared/HDB/hdblcm/hdblcm --action=register_rename_system  --groupid=1000 --lss_groupid=79

This should bring up the database processes as below

sid-hdb-s4h: #/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function GetProcessList

STEP 5: EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-hdb-s4h:/install #/sapmnt/S4H/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM20SP22_5-80003424.SAR

STEP 6: RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst, although we want to keep SID same as standard - S4H we need to run the procedure so that the process installs the missing items.

sid-hdb-s4h:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcals4hci SAPINST_GUI_HOSTNAME=vhcals4hci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-hdb-s4h.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

You get screen below:

At above screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System S4H and Target System S4H:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Connectivity enter Instance Number 02 and Password Welcome_2Welocme_2. Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button – Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next

At next screen Warning click OK

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the above screen Keep Existing Licenses accept unchecked of Keep existing licenses. Click on Next

At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next

TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

(1) Error occurs when executing command 'changekey' using the command line tool 'rsecssfx'.

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

sid-hdb-s4h:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 01 -function StartSystem ALL
sid-hdb-s4h:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H.

Standard users are as follows:
HANA DB – Instance 02 SYSTEM /<Master Password> or as you changed in above
Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome1

STEP 7: Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC

Adapt RFC Connections if needed

ABAP connections:
• LOCAL_RFC
• S4HCLNT100 (and other clients)
• S4H_RFC

HTTP connections:
• ADS (pointing to the JAVA server after PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA /ADS)
• LOCAL_HTTP
• LOCAL_HTTPS
• S4FIN_HTTPS

SAP Enable Now Web Assistant

Adapt the Fiori notification URL

Adapt Enterprise Search

Apply product license keys

Install software product license key: Technical restrictions may apply if you don’t install the license. Use the link to obtain license key.
HANA DB license key can be installed via HANA Studio (Preferences -> License)
From SAP S/4HANA 1909 onwards the license key is installed via SAP logon tCode SLICENSE

Further post-installation checks

Install SAP client tools on your local computers

You can take a full backup and remove the temporary links that were setup for S4H

In client 000 fix transport configuration. Enter tCode SE06 and reinstall CTS transport system.

Adapt any SAP parameters required

The database is provided with log mode overwrite and you may like to change that as needed.

PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA / ADS

STEP 1: Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. Total filesystem needed is min 70GB for installation.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: Extract files 51059242_5.ZIP  in /sapmedia

sid-j2e:/sapmedia# unzip 51059242_5.ZIP

We will install Java instance from files in  /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

cd /sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/J2E

sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat sapmnt_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat usrsap_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51059242_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP32ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-j2e:/install #/sapmnt/J2E/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR

STEP 5: Rename instance using sapinst

sid-j2e:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcalj2eci SAPINST_SLP_MODE=false

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-j2e.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At the screen Software Integrity click on Next

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System J2E
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen Database System Type keep the default selection SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise for Business Suite

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Operating System User for SAP Database Administrator enter the password for sybj2e and User ID and Click on Next

At the screen SAP ASE Database System Parameters accept or change ports and Click on Next

At the screen Database User Passwords enter the passwords for user sa, sapsa, sapsso, SAPSR3DB which is Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next
At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next

TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.

At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next

Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

 

You can manually start/stop the SAP Java instance J2E using old commands

sid-j2e:/install # su - j2eadm
sid-j2e:j2eadm > startsap

To access JAVA server as SAP Netweaver Administrator the URL is:
https://sid-j2e.dummy.nodomain:50000/nwa

Standard users are as follows:

JAVA Administrator – Administrator / <Master Password> ;
Java user BPINST/Welcome2Welcome2

STEP 6: Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf - Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Apply product license keys if you haven't installed during swpm install step before. Technical restrictions may apply if you don’t install the license. Use the link to obtain license key. SAPNetweaver 7.5 J2EE license key has to be installed via SAP Netweaver Administrator

Further post-installation checks

Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder.

SUPPORT TICKETS:

If you have any difficulty downloading the media open OSS message using component XX-SER-SAPSMP-SWC. If you have issues with technical deployment open message with component BC-INS-SRN.

OTHER REFERENCES:

SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual setup time
SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Demo Guides

Blogs with known issues (2022 / 2021 / 2020), continuously updated

2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

Thank you. Hope you enjoyed the installation.

Mahesh Sardesai
Product Expert – S/4HANA

entry.title: Create Purchasing Contract with conditions via API Purchase Contracts (Version 2)
entry.content:
Hello SAP,

We are trying to create purchasing contracts with conditions, i.e., entities:

  • A_PurContrItmCndnAmountType (Item Condition Amount)
  • A_PurContrItmCndnScalesType (Item Condition Scales)
  • A_PurContrItmCndnValdtyType (Item COndition Validity)

However, the interface Purchase Contracts (Version 2) / API_PURCHASECONTRACT_PROCESS_SRV;v=2 provided for this purpose does not seem to support conditions during initial creation. Unfortunately, we cannot find any meaningful documentation and are therefore wondering whether this is generally not technically possible or what method we need to use to create purchasing contracts with conditions in SAP.

It is important to note that these conditions should be different from those created in the purchasing info record. In other words, from a technical/business perspective, we are getting even better purchasing conditions in the purchasing contract than in the purchasing info record.

In short: How can purchasing contracts with conditions from another external system be created

entry.title: Re: UKM_CASE: rejected document still has the status "blo...
entry.content:
Yes, rejected entries still carry the “Blocked” overall status — that’s standard system behavior. To hide them, you either need to use query variants/filters or implement a custom enhancement that sets a separate status for rejected cases.

SAP recommends using Decision Codes (Release, Reject, etc.) to distinguish the outcome of blocked documents. For operational users, provide query variants or custom reports that filter out rejected cases. If the business needs a hard separation, a small enhancement to set a distinct overall status for rejected documents is the cleanest way.

entry.title: Valuation Price Field Is Read-Only for Items Sourced from Product Catalog
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I'm currently working with the new Fiori application F1639A – My Purchase Requisitions (New) and have encountered a challenge:

Requirement: I need to source items from the Catalog but also modify the "Valuation Price" field before creating the requisition.

Previous Solution: In the deprecated application, we successfully achieved this by removing the Catalog ID through a BADI implementation.

Current Issue: This approach no longer seems to work in the new application.

Has anyone found a workaround or alternative solution to enable editing of the Valuation Price for catalog-sourced items in F1639A? 

Any guidance or suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance for your help.

entry.title: Characters limit issue on the Comments section for Employee and Matrix Managers on the PM Forms
entry.content:
We’ve identified an issue with the character‑limit validation in our Performance form template and are seeking guidance on how to resolve it.

Our requirement is for Employees, Managers, and all Matrix Managers to be restricted to 1000 characters when entering comments on the form. The template is already configured with this 1000‑character limit.

However, the current route map uses the Collaboration step type for Employees, Managers, and all Matrix Managers, with the Manager defined as the exit user. The problem is that the character limit is only being enforced for the Manager when the form is routed forward. Employees and Matrix Managers are still able to exceed the 1000‑character limit, despite the configuration.

Has anyone encountered this issue before, or is there a recommended configuration or workaround to ensure the character limit is enforced consistently for all roles at the Collaboration step?

Any insights would be greatly appreciated.

SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals

entry.title: Re: LMS External instructor marking attendance
entry.content:
Hi @DriesMoerman ,

The most possible reason based on both of these options missing is that the Class has a cost associated to it, meaning the Purchasing Option on the Class is set to anything but 'No Charge'.

You can validate this on the Class entity > Purchasing tab > Purchasing option (if it says 'Inherit Item Chargeback Settings', then check the value for the same in the next section of this page and it will let you know what is the Purchasing Option inherited from the parent item.

Instructors are by design restricted from adding walk-ins to classes if the class has a cost associated.

This is explained in the following KBA: 2281678 - No option to "Add Users" on Past Classes for instructor 

Marking completions is also not possible by default if the class has any other purchasing option beyond 'No Charge', unless you actually enable the related configuration:

System Administration > Configuration > System Configuration > FINANCE > enableRecordCompletionInInstructorViewWithFinance > set to 'true' if you would like to allow Instructors to record completions on classes with a financial purchase.

Configuration property explanation: 

# This configuration allows the addition of learning history (Record Completion) from the Instructor View when a class's purchasing options are something other than No Charge. This includes purchasing options: Distribute Charges to Specified Account Code, Charge to Buyer's Authorized Account Code, or Charge to Buyer's Specified Account Code.
# Default configuration is false. Only classes with purchasing option of No Charge will support record completion.

I hope this explanation was helpful and answered your question.

Best regards,
Enikő

entry.title: Re: Create Purchasing Contract with conditions via API Pu...
entry.content:
Below are the limitations and considerations

  • No direct POST for conditions: You cannot create conditions in one payload with the contract.
  • Maintenance overhead: Conditions must be added separately, either manually or via extensibility.
  • Audit/compliance: SAP deliberately restricts condition creation via API to avoid uncontrolled pricing changes.
  • Best practice: Use contracts for quantity/validity control and info records for pricing; only override conditions in contracts when necessary.

For your ask on documentation, you can check in the below areas

Purchase Contracts (Version 2) 

Here, you’ll see POST/PATCH operations only for A_PurchaseContractType and A_PurchaseContractItemType. Condition entities are visible in the model but not in the operations list.

entry.title: Intercompany Invoice IDoc not posting gainst the original Purchase Order in S/4HANA Public
entry.content:
We are working with an SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud intercompany scenario and have encountered unexpected behavior regarding how the incoming intercompany supplier invoice is posted in the receiving company code.

Our Scenario (Public Cloud – Intercompany PO → Outbound Delivery → Invoice)

  1. Company Code A creates an Intercompany Purchase Order to Company Code Company Code B.
  2. In Company Code B, the system automatically generates the Intercompany Outbound Delivery.
  3. Company Code B posts the Intercompany Billing Document, which in turn triggers an IDoc toward Company Code A.
  4. The IDoc is successfully processed in Company Code A and creates a Journal Entry.

The Issue

Although the accounting document is created correctly in Company Code A, it is not linked to the original Purchase Order.
We expected the invoice posting via IDoc to update or reference the PO, but the journal entry contains no PO number, no PO item, and no PO history update. But we can see it in the message that the references are in the iDoc. But we do not see it in the PO document flow. 

 

 

Our question

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, should the IDoc-based incoming intercompany supplier invoice post directly against the original Purchase Order in the receiving company?

  • If yes, which configuration or business setting ensures that the IDoc updates the PO history?
  • If no, what is the expected standard system behavior in Public Cloud, and is the journal entry intentionally not linked to the PO?

Any insights, updated documentation references, or examples from other Public Cloud systems would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Re: SAP Integration Suite Workflows with Job Scheduling Service 🚀
entry.content:
Hi @valentincadart,

I'm expert only on the Job Scheduling service, so I can speculate a bit, plus share what I've heard from others.

First thing is what I've heard - about easier control on when do you want your iFlow to be executed - yes you can do that directly in the iFlow, but hen you need to redeploy the whole thing etc. When you have the trigger in Job Scheduling service you can just change the schedule, or add a new one, or have multiple. You can also easily enable or disable scheduled/jobs. We have a very flexible scheduling capabilities and different formats to express specific schedule.

The second thing can be about alerting and monitoring.
For alerting we have build-in integration with SAP Alert Notification Service where you get alerts for failing or successful job executions and decide what to do (you can even start automatic remediation with services like Automation Pilot). 
In addition - you can use the dashboard to monitor the jobs and the executions (new improvements and analytics are coming soon). If that is not enough there is build-in integration with Cloud ALM: Job & Automation monitoring - where you can monitor jobs from different instances, systems and schedulers in just one place.

I'm curious to hear your perspective 🙂

entry.title: Re: Valuation Price Field Is Read-Only for Items Sourced...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the new Fiori app F1639A (“My Purchase Requisitions – New”) does not allow direct editing of the Valuation Price for catalog-sourced items. This is by design: once a catalog ID is attached, the price is locked to ensure compliance with the catalog contract. The earlier workaround (removing the catalog ID via BAdI) is not supported in the new app.

Below are Workarounds / Alternatives

Use non-catalog sourcing for editable price
If you need to override catalog pricing, source the item via manual entry or info record/contract reference instead of catalog. This keeps the valuation price field open for editing.

Custom logic via extensibility
In Public Cloud, only certain In-App Extensibility points are available. You can explore the BAdI to influence price determination. However, these typically allow substitution of source-of-supply pricing, not manual editing of catalog prices.

Workflow / approval route
If business requires adjusting catalog prices (e.g., negotiated discounts), best practice is to handle this via contract conditions or supplier catalog maintenance, not at PR level. You can set up workflow rules so that PRs with catalog items route for approval if the catalog price is not acceptable.

 Angelika

entry.title: Re: Purchase order accruals POAC and periodic billing plan
entry.content:
Why accruals behave this way is because, the POAC program calculates accruals based on delivery date and GR/SES postings at the item level. Even if you define a periodic invoicing plan with monthly billing dates, the accrual engine does not read those billing plan dates. It only looks at the delivery date of the PO item (or service entry sheet acceptance). That is why in your test:

  • Delivery date = 31/12 → accrual = 0 until December.
  • Delivery date = 28/02 → accrual = full 1200 in February.

For service materials, multiple deliveries are not possible, so you can’t split the PO item into monthly deliveries to align accruals.

Below are the workarounds / alternatives

Split PO items by period
Create 12 PO items (one per month, each with delivery date at month end, value 100). This way, POAC will accrue correctly per month. Downside: more PO lines to manage.

Use Service Entry Sheets (SES)
Post SES monthly for the service material. POAC will accrue based on SES acceptance dates. This aligns accruals with service consumption rather than delivery date.

Custom enhancement (BAdI / substitution)
Technically, you could enhance POAC logic to read billing plan dates instead of delivery date. This requires a custom development (e.g., BAdI FINS_ACCRUAL_POSTING or substitution in accrual engine). In Public Cloud, extensibility is limited, so this may not be feasible unless SAP releases a standard enhancement.

Alternative reporting
Instead of relying on POAC, build a custom accrual report that reads billing plan dates and calculates expected accruals. This can be done via CDS view on PurchaseOrderBillingPlan and PurchaseOrderItem. You’d then post manual accruals or journal entries based on this report.

entry.title: What is eCATT error TT377 Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3) ?
entry.content:

The eCATT was created on an old ABAP system (ECC 6.0, ABAP 7.31) and it contains only one TCD command (Batch Input).

I see there are other same questions but with different VERBS-NAME (e.g. CREATEOBJECT), CATT (e.g. GETGUISERVICES, CREATE, <none>, SHOWDATA) or Callno, the answers were unclear what it means and what to do.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: What is eCATT error TT377 Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3) ?
entry.content:
The error message TT377 "Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3)" means that the list of called OCX control methods (called "verbs") is different from the list of called OCX control methods when the eCATT was recorded:

  • The placeholder &1 ("VERBS-NAME") is the OCX control method ("verb") currently called.
  • The placeholder &2 ("CATT") is the OCX control method which was recorded at the time the eCATT was recorded, and which is expected.

For information:

  • The error message TT377 is sent by the function module CAT_CONTROLS_PLAYBACK.
  • The list of the recorded OCX verbs is stored in the table ECSCR_TVER.

I have no idea if this discrepancy between expected and actual verbs is critical or not, but by default it makes the script fail.

Solution

In my case, if I wrap the TCD command between the commands MESSAGE (MODE = 'A',  EXIT = <empty value>, MSGTYP = 'A', MSGID = 'TT', MSGNR = 377) and ENDMESSAGE (empty interface).

  • MODE = 'A' means "Allowed", i.e. if the message happens, there's no error, the next command inside the block MESSAGE/ENDMESSAGE is run, or if there's none the command after the block. For information, the standard behavior for the "A" (abort) error messages is MODE = 'F' (Failure),  EXIT = 'X' (execution skips to the ENDMESSAGE command).

If you don't want to use the block MESSAGE/ENDMESSAGE, you may rerecord the TCD command in the current system with exactly the same screens, and put back the original TCD command interface (for instance, type the variables manually).

For more information

About eCATT, see here: eCATT: extended Computer Aided Test Tool (BC-TWB-TST-ECA) | SAP Help Portal.

You may also refer to the list of all eCATT commands here: eCATT Command Reference | SAP Help Portal

NB: I'd be thankful to anyone who can explain the rationale of comparing the expected (when the TCD was recorded) and actual (when the TCD runs) lists of OCX control verbs.

entry.title: Secure SAP–AI Integration Using Advantco OpenPGP Services
entry.content:
Secure SAP–AI Integration Using Advantco OpenPGP Services

1. Purpose and Scope

This article defines a secure, deployment-agnostic reference architecture for integrating SAP backend systems with external AI agents using OpenPGP-based cryptographic services provided by Advantco. The architecture separates cryptographic processing from data transport, ensuring that encryption, decryption, signing, and verification are performed by a dedicated cryptographic service layer, while message routing and orchestration remain the responsibility of the calling application or integration layer.

The architecture is intended for hybrid enterprise environments in which SAP backend systems may be deployed on-premise, in private cloud, on hyperscalers, or under RISE with SAP. AI agents may run on external platforms or managed AI services. Advantco OpenPGP services are exposed as APIs (REST and/or SOAP) and may be deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform or an equivalent enterprise runtime. This document describes a logical reference architecture and does not prescribe a specific deployment topology.

The scope of this document is limited to secure data exchange and trust establishment between SAP systems and AI agents. AI model behavior, prompt engineering, SAP business logic, and transport-level protocol selection are out of scope except where they affect security guarantees.

2. Architectural Rationale

Integrating SAP systems with external AI capabilities introduces a trust boundary between SAP-controlled environments and systems that operate outside SAP governance. This architecture addresses that boundary by enforcing message-level security that is independent of transport mechanisms and network topology.

Rather than embedding cryptographic logic into SAP applications or integration flows, the architecture externalizes OpenPGP operations into a dedicated cryptographic service layer. This allows encryption, decryption, signing, and verification to be centrally governed, audited, and evolved without requiring changes to SAP business applications. Transport and routing of messages remain the responsibility of SAP applications or integration components, preventing the cryptographic services from becoming an implicit integration broker.

3. Architectural Overview

The architecture consists of four logical concerns: SAP backend systems, an optional integration or orchestration layer, Advantco OpenPGP cryptographic services, and an external AI agent ecosystem.

SAP backend systems produce and consume business data but do not perform cryptographic operations directly. They rely on an integration or orchestration layer such as SAP Integration Suite, a SAP BTP application, or other middleware to coordinate message exchange with external systems where required.

Advantco OpenPGP services provide cryptographic transformation via APIs only. They do not perform message routing, transport, or forwarding.

External AI agents receive only signed and encrypted payloads and return responses in signed and encrypted form. Unencrypted payloads exist only within SAP-controlled trust boundaries.

Advantco OpenPGP provides cryptographic APIs only and returns results to the caller. Message transport and routing are handled by SAP or integration components and are not performed by Advantco.

4. Architecture Structure

From a business perspective, the architecture enables SAP processes to consume AI-generated insights without relinquishing control over data confidentiality or trust decisions. AI systems may influence SAP outcomes, but only after cryptographic validation and SAP-side authorization.

From an application perspective, the architecture separates responsibilities clearly. SAP backend systems focus on business logic. The integration or orchestration layer handles routing, retries, and protocol adaptation. Advantco OpenPGP services handle cryptographic transformation. AI agents handle AI processing only.

From an integration perspective, communication is message-based and transport-agnostic. Payload-level security is applied using OpenPGP before data crosses trust boundaries, ensuring that transport security is an additional layer rather than the primary protection mechanism.

From a data perspective, unencrypted payload exists only within SAP-controlled environments. Outside those boundaries, data is always exchanged in signed and encrypted form, accompanied by cryptographic metadata required for verification and audit.

5. Component Responsibilities

SAP backend systems remain the authoritative producers and consumers of business data. They initiate outbound requests and consume inbound results but delegate cryptographic processing to external services. SAP systems do not store or manage cryptographic private keys.

The integration or orchestration layer (where present) is responsible for transport, routing, protocol handling, retries, correlation, and error handling. It invokes Advantco OpenPGP APIs as required and forwards encrypted payloads to external AI agents, and returns verified payloads to SAP systems. It does not perform cryptographic operations beyond invoking the cryptographic service APIs.

Advantco OpenPGP services provide cryptographic operations as APIs. For outbound processing, they accept payloads and perform optional compression, message digest generation, digital signing, and OpenPGP hybrid encryption. For inbound processing, they accept encrypted payloads, verify digital signatures, decrypt content under governed key controls, and return verified payloads to the caller. These services are stateless with respect to message routing and do not forward data to external systems.

External AI agents operate outside the SAP trust boundary and are treated as untrusted by default. They can only process data that they have successfully decrypted and verified using trusted SAP public keys. AI agents sign and encrypt all outbound responses using their own private keys and do not receive access to SAP private keys or verified SAP payloads.

Key management is handled by a centralized Key Management Service that governs cryptographic key lifecycles, enforces usage policies, and records audit events. Agent identities are established by registering and allow-listing agent public keys, typically identified by fingerprints or key identifiers. Private keys remain protected and are never exposed outside the cryptographic service boundary.

6. Message Exchange

The Advantco OpenPGP APIs may be invoked directly by SAP applications or by an intermediate integration or orchestration layer. In all cases, Advantco performs cryptographic transformation only and does not forward messages.

In the outbound flow, SAP backend systems submit payloads for signing and encryption via the Advantco OpenPGP service. The service returns a signed and encrypted payload to the caller, which is responsible for forwarding the encrypted message to the external AI agent.

In the inbound flow, the external AI agent produces a signed and encrypted response. The encrypted response is submitted to the Advantco OpenPGP service for verification and decryption. The service returns a verified payload to the caller, which delivers the result to the SAP backend system.

The sequence diagram above illustrates the strict request–response nature of the Advantco OpenPGP APIs and the separation of cryptographic processing from message transport and routing.

7. Trust and Security Model

Trust in this architecture is based on cryptographic identity rather than network location. Public-key identities establish which parties may exchange data, while centralized key governance determines how keys may be used. By default, no shared secrets are required between SAP systems and AI agents.

Confidentiality is enforced through OpenPGP hybrid encryption. Integrity and authenticity are enforced through digital signatures. Auditability is provided through centralized logging of cryptographic operations. Replay protection is enforced by the receiving side using message identifiers, timestamps, and validity windows.

Cryptographic validity does not imply business authorization. AI-generated responses or instructions must still be validated against schemas, allow-listed actions, and SAP-side authorization rules before affecting SAP business processes.

8. Deployment Considerations

The architecture supports a wide range of deployment models, including scenarios in which SAP systems and integration components run on SAP BTP while cryptographic services are cloud-hosted and AI agents operate on external platforms. Security and correctness depend on logical separation of responsibilities rather than physical co-location.

As a concrete implementation option, Advantco OpenPGP services are available for deployment on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). In this model, the cryptographic services run as managed applications or services on SAP BTP and expose OpenPGP functionality through REST and/or SOAP APIs. SAP backend systems and SAP integration components can invoke these APIs directly using standard SAP-supported connectivity mechanisms. Deployment on SAP BTP does not change the logical architecture described in this document; Advantco OpenPGP continues to operate strictly as a cryptographic service and does not perform message routing or transport.

9. Conclusion

This reference architecture defines a clear separation between cryptographic services, message transport, and business logic for secure SAP–AI integration. By exposing OpenPGP operations as governed APIs and keeping data transport outside the cryptographic service boundary, the architecture enables strong security guarantees while remaining flexible, deployment-neutral, and suitable for enterprise use.

10. Sources

https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform.html
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4880
https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/
https://www.advantco.com/sap-integration-adapters/sap-pgp-integration

entry.title: Re: Update all worksheets & Guidelines - Compensation Module
entry.content:
Hi @magdalena_grabowicz 

1. Yes in my experience most organizations do not freeze data and run Update all worksheets job overnight during planning cycle (in Compensation, not VarPay). Customers can now schedule these jobs themselves since 2h 2025. The main drawback of "Update a specific worksheet" is that it doesn't allow people to move between worksheets based on planner change. Not even sure that it reflect eligibility the right way I'd need to test. The speed of all jobs has increased tremendously over the past release so for 11k employees I don't think it would take more than 20-30 minutes at this time.

2. It's rare to not have either of these two but it happens, for example for public sector organizations where increase % are negociated with unions, guideline based on the category of jobs you are in. Or in other cases predominantly based on only the payscale structure: Understanding SuccessFactors Pay Scale Structure and its related features

Best,

Xavier

entry.title: Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM)
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily introduces the configuration of Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM).

If anything regarding TRM account determination has not been clarified in this blog post, please leave a comment and we will try to refine it as soon as possible.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is mandatory:

  • Basic knowledge in general ledger accounting, account receivables, account payables, e.g., document types, posting keys, account types (e.g., D - Customers, K - Vendors, S - G/L accounts).
  • Valuation areas in TRM and how they are linked to accounting principles and ledgers.
    • Paying valuation area is linked to the leading ledger.
    • Nonpaying valuation areas are linked to the non-leading ledgers.
  • Update types in TRM and how they are determined from valuation area-independent operational cash flows, valuation area-dependent business transactions (e.g., valuation, accrual, derived business transactions), etc.
  • Account assignment references in TRM and how they are derived.
  • TRM position management and position change categories.
  • Bank account management in cash management.

Configuration activities

Configuration activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) or IMG activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) will be used in this blog post:

 

Configuration activities in Public Cloud

Configuration Table

IMG activities in Private Cloud

102121 - Define Account Symbols

TRAC_ACCSYMB

TRAC_ACCSYMB_T

KONTENFINDUNG - Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management

103014 - Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management

TRAC_POSTRULE

TRAC_POSTRULE_T

TRAC_DFTRULE1

TRAC_DFTRULE2

TRACC_ACCSYMBREP

KONTENFINDUNG - Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management

105589 - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers

ATPRA

FIBL_V_ATPRA_FI - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers, or TR_IMG_PRQ_VZA - Define Clearing Account for Payment Requests

102097 - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components

TRLAC_DFT_PMC

TR_FS_ART_BESTFTBETR - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components

This blog post will be described in the context of public cloud.

TRM account determination logic at a glance

Evaluate the business requirement

Before starting configuration for account determination, please evaluate the business requirement for posting:

  1. What is the update type for which the posting should be generated? What is the economic essence behind it?
  2. What are the categories for the debit and credit entries of this posting? Is it a posting for position (book value) of the financial instrument, or customer or vendor subledger, or bank clearing account, or profit or loss account (with account assignment required like cost center), or others?
  3. What are the G/L account numbers should be used?

The order of configuration

  1. Define account symbols and specify the posting categories for the account symbols in configuration activity 102121. The available posting categories are:
    • 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency
    • 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency
    • 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency
    • 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency
    • 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency
    • 6 - Other G/L Posting in Position Currency
    • 7 - Other G/L Posting in Payment Currency
    • 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency
    • 11- Tax Posting in Payment Currency
  2. Define posting specifications in node ‘Definition of Posting Specifications’ of configuration activity 103014, including document type, posting keys, account symbols, special G/L indicators (optional, only when posting to customer/vendor subledger) for debit and credit entries of the posting specification.
  3. Assign the posting specifications to the update types in node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014.
  4. Assign the G/L accounts to the account symbols, account assignment references (optional, but usually needed for most cases), valuation areas (optional), currencies (optional) in node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014.
  5.  

A simple illustration

MM1150- is the update type of interest capitalization from the investment transactions of money market. MM1150- is assigned with the posting specification 13700, which can be seen from the node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014.

In the node ‘Definition of Posting Specifications’ of configuration activity 103014, check the posting specification 13700:

  • Document type: SA
  • Debit entry: posting key 40, account symbol 1 (posting category: 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency)
  • Debit entry: posting key 50, account symbol 4.1.3 (4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency)

The account symbols are created and their posting categories are specified in configuration activity 102121:

In the node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014:

  • Assign G/L account 18030000 (Long Term Investments, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.
  • Assign G/L account 70200000 (Interest Income, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 4.1.1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.

Posting result: when running TBB1/TPM10 for the interest capitalization flow using update type MM1150- from an investment money market transaction with account assignment reference 201100000000, the posting journal entry would be debiting 18030000 and crediting 70200000.

Position posting (book value) in position currency

To post to the financial assets or liabilities reflected in the position accounts of the financial instruments, please use an account symbol with posting category 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency.

The position accounts of the financial instruments include (but are not limited to) the long/short term investment or debt arising from debt instruments (e.g., deposits, CDs, loans, bonds, ABS/MBS), equity investments (e.g., stock, shareholding), fund investments, derivative assets or liabilities from derivative financial instruments (e.g., forwards, options, swaps), receivables or payables arising from trade finance contracts like letter of credit, regardless of how the G/L accounts of positions are named in your chart of accounts.

Usually, if an account symbol with posting category 1 is involved in an update type where the position change category cannot be automatically determined, especially for the update type mapped to an operational cash flow from financial transactions or securities account management, the update type should be assigned with a proper position change category in the configuration activity 102097 - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components, to ensure that the effects on position changes in TRM position management and position accounts postings are consistent.

Examples:

Flow Type

Direction

1100

1010

Credit position posting

1150

Interest capitalization

-

MM1150-

Investment / Interest Capitalization

1011

Post Purchase Value

Debit position posting

Bank clearing account or Payment request clearing account

This section elaborates the usage of posting category 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency. Let’s have a look at the following example:

In configuration activity 102121 - Define Account Symbols, account symbol 3 “Bank clearing” is defined with posting category 3.

In the node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014, in the field “G/L account”, “+++++++080” is assigned to the account symbol 3.

The posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1100- (principal increase of investment transaction of money market). Posting spec 11100 credits account symbol 3.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘Without’ is selected for “Payment Request” option of direction “outflow”, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “Payment Request” is empty for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

The posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 0011001080.

How is 0011001080 determined?

System first finds out the G/L account of house bank DEBK1 and account ID DEAC1 of company code 1010, it is 0011001000 (the bank main account).

System them applies +++++++080 (the “G/L account” assigned to account symbol 3) to the bank main account 0011001000:

  • The first 7 digits of 0011001000—0011001—are retained because of +++++++
  • The last 3 digits of 0011001000 are replaced with 080
  • Combining 0011001 and 080 results in the bank sub-account (bank clearing account) 0011001080, which is then used for posting.

Let’s create another investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘With’ is selected for “Payment Request” option of direction “outflow”, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1, the payer/payee and its partner bank (which are required in payment request) are also specified in the sub-area “Payment”.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “payment request” is “X” for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

Now, the posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 21900000 (Payment Request Clearing Account (TRM)).

How is 21900000 determined?

When the “payment request” is ‘X’, system abandons the use of the bank clearing account. Instead, system retrieves the account maintained in configuration activity 105589 - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers.

In TBB1, you can also check the payment log, in which you can find the payment request number.

Afterwards, please use the app Automatic Payment Transactions for Payment Request (transaction F111) to process the payment request, create accounting document debiting 21900000 and crediting bank clearing account (determined by payment program instead of TRM), and create the payment medium if necessary. The detailed process is not elaborated herein.

Summary:

  • Bank clearing account is used when the corresponding cash flow is without payment request.
  • Bank clearing account is usually applicable to the bank-initiated payments (for example, for most of the incoming payments), and the open item of bank clearing account should be later reconciled with bank statement item.
  • Payment request clearing account is used when the corresponding cash flow is with payment request.
  • Payment request is usually applicable to the corporate-initiated payment scenario, in which the corporate should inform the bank to proceed with the payment, e.g., via payment medium sent to bank.

Paying/Nonpaying valuation areas and Postings to customers or vendors

You may already aware that different posting specifications can be assigned to the same update type in the node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014, differentiated by the second column “P” (“Payment Transaction”) and third column “Posted in Pay. VA”. For example:

  • 11100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” unselected and “Not Specified” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
  • 71100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
  • 81100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Nonpaying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.

If “P” is selected, it means the intention is to generate posting to customer or vendor subledger (FI-AR / FI-AP). In this example, the purposes of 71100 and 81100 are to post to vendor in credit side.

The posting spec 11100 assigned to “P” unselected MM1100- has been explained in above section “Bank clearing account or Payment request clearing account”, in which credit entry is posted to bank clearing account or payment request clearing account, not vendor or customer.

Details of posting spec 71100 and 81100:

  • 71100 is used for the postings in paying valuation area.
    • Credit entry’s account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry’s posting key must be relevant to account type D (customer) or K (vendor). In this example, the posting key 34 is used, 34 is a posting key for account type K.
  • 81100 is used for the postings in nonpaying valuation areas.
    • Credit entry’s account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry’s posting key must be relevant to account type S (G/L accounts), instead of account type D or K. In this example, the posting key 50 is used.

Let’s use the following example to illustrate the outcome of this configuration.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘to customer’ is selected for “Posting” option of direction “outflow”, which means for outflows, the postings should post to customer or vendor. Although it is called “to customer”, it can also post to vendor (actually it is controlled by posting key). In this example, because posting key 34 is used, and posting key 34 is relevant to account type K, it posts to vendor instead of customer.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “Payment Transaction” is “X” for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-), indicating that it should post to customer or vendor. And the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee (10537001 in this example) in sub-area “Payment” should be the customer or vendor.

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025 for all valuation areas (paying and nonpaying valuation areas). Check posting log:

Because 1100 cash flow is “Payment Transaction” = “X” and DE0 is the paying valuation area, MM1100- uses the posting spec 71100 within DE0. 71100 uses the posting key 34 which is for vendor (account type K), so system knows that it should post to the vendor 10537001 (the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee of payment details in the transaction). In above screen-shot of posting log, the G/L account of posting key 34 is empty (it is not a bug!), this is because the TRM accounting interface passes on the vendor account 10537001 to FI, and FI determines the reconciliation account from the vendor master data of 10537001. Checking the line item of the journal entry, you will see it credits the vendor 10537001, and its reconciliation account 21100000 is also determined by FI and stored in the line item. To ensure successful posting, the business partner 10537001 must be extended to the BP role FLVN00 (FI supplier) and the reconciliation account of vendor 10537001 must be maintained in advance.

Because 1100 cash flow is “Payment Transaction” = “X” and 002 and 003 are the nonpaying valuation area, MM1100- use the posting spec 81100 within 002 and 003. 81100 uses the posting key 50 which is for account type S, and from the screen-shot of posting log from TRM side, you already see the reconciliation account 21100000 has been determined in TRM.

How does TRM determine reconciliation account 21100000 for nonpaying valuation areas:

  • 81100 uses the account symbol V.0 with posting category 2, so TRM knows it should post to vendor or customer.
  • TRM checks the corresponding posting spec 71100 used in the paying valuation area, 71100 uses posting key 34 for account symbol V.0, posting key 34 indicates that the posting is done to vendor.
  • Then TRM determines that the 81100 should also post to vendor.
  • TRM finds out the reconciliation account 21100000 from the vendor master data of 10537001.
  • 81100 directly posts to 21100000 using posting key 50 (211000000 is provided in the TRM accounting interface to FI, and FI uses it for posting directly).

Therefore, the credit postings in all valuation areas are recorded in reconciliation account 21100000 of vendor 10537001.

A frequently asked question is that why different posting keys should be used for customer or vendor postings in paying and nonpaying valuation areas for the same update type. In other modules (e.g. FI-AR, FI-AP), the postings to customers or vendors can be done in all ledgers (leading and non-leading ledgers) at the same time without specifying a ledger group, so posting keys for account type D or K can be used in journals of all ledgers. TRM always performs the valuation area-dependent postings, that means, postings from paying valuation area are posted to the ledger group containing the leading ledger only, postings from a nonpaying valuation area are posted to the ledger group containing the corresponding non-leading ledger only. For leading ledger’s postings for customer or vendors, posting keys for account type D or K should be used (and later clearing can be performed); however, for the non-leading ledger only postings, posting keys for account type D or K are unacceptable (design of FI), that’s why it is needed to use posting keys 40, 50 (or other posting keys for account type S) for vendor or customer postings arising from the nonpaying valuation areas.

Additional notes:

  • As already stated, and emphasize again, whether posting to vendor or customer is decided by the account type of the posting key specified in the posting spec assigned to the update type with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
  • The document type used for paying valuation area related posting spec should allow postings to account type D or K, if any account symbol in the posting spec uses posting category 2.
  • An account symbol with posting category 2 should be used exclusively with posting keys for either vendors or customers (not both) across all posting specifications. For example, if account symbol V.0 is already used with posting key 34 (account type K) in a posting spec, do not use V.0 with any posting keys for account type D (e.g., 01, 11) in other posting specs. Improper configuration of this kind will trigger error message TPM_TRAC1 040 ("Cannot determine account type for account symbol V.0") in TBB1/TPM10.
  • Postings to special G/L accounts are also possible. To achieve it, please configure posting specifications like below:
    • Posting spec of paying valuation area:
      • Use posting key 09 (debit) or 19 (credit) for customer
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for customer (account type D)
      • Or, use posting key 29 (debit) or 39 (credit) for vendor
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for vendor (account type K)
    • Posting spec of nonpaying valuation areas:
      • Use posting key 40 (debit) or 50 (credit) for customer or vendor
        • Use the same Special G/L indicator used in the corresponding posting spec for paying valuation area.
    • The mapping of special G/L accounts to reconciliation accounts should already be configured in FI for the special G/L indicators of account type D or K.
    • Account determination logic:
      • Paying valuation area: similar to reconciliation account posting, TRM passes on the vendor/customer account and special G/L indicator to FI via accounting interface, FI will determine the special G/L account.
      • Nonpaying valuation areas: also similar to reconciliation account posting, TRM checks the posting keys of corresponding posting spec of paying valuation area, determines it is for vendor or customer, finds out the reconciliation account, and determines the special G/L account of the reconciliation account and the special G/L indicator of account type D or K, pass on the special G/L account to FI posting.
  • The reconciliation account or special G/L account is used for vendor or customer related postings, and they are automatically determined (by FI for paying VA, or by TRM for nonpaying VAs), therefore, it is not necessary to assign and please do NOT assign G/L accounts to account symbols with posting category 2 in node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014.
  • There is another node “Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs” (table TRAC_DFTRULE2) in configuration activity 103014, it is used to assign different posting specs for the same update type in different valuation areas and company codes, if necessary. Considering together with the node “Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs” (table TRAC_DFTRULE1), the posting spec determination logic for an update type in a valuation area is like below:
IF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE2
  Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE2
ELSEIF the valuation area is paying valuation area
  IF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'P' (paying valuation area)
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'P'
  ELSEIF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = '' (not specified)
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = ''
  ELSE
    Raise error message
ELSEIF the valuation area is NOT paying valuation area
  IF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'N'(nonpaying valuation area)
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'N'
  ELSEIF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = ''
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = ''
  ELSE
    Raise error message

Profit-related postings

The posting category 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency or 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency should be used for the account symbols assigned with the profit or loss G/L accounts which are set up as primary cost elements (cost element category 1 - Primary costs).

The primary cost element needs account assignments (e.g., cost center) during posting. Only with posting category 4 or 5, the account assignments in treasury position indicator will be passed on to accounting document line items.

A frequently seen issue: the cost center appears in the position indicator of a treasury transaction (via any workable means mentioned in blog post Account Assignment in TRM Financial Transactions - Cost Center). However, this cost center is not used for postings done by TBB1 or TPM10, and error message like “account assignment can’t be determined for cost element” is raised. The cause could be that the relevant account symbols (assigned with cost element in node “Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols”) doesn’t use posting category 4 or 5.

Currency swap between position currency and payment currency

The usage of posting category 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency is special. In this example, the account symbol 9.1.4 uses posting category 10.

Account symbol 9.1.4 is not used in any posting specs.

A technical clearing account 22549000 is assigned to account symbol 9.1.4.

In the names of posting categories, you always see “…in payment currency” or “…in position currency”, these indicate which currency is the transaction currency in accounting documents—payment currency or position currency.

When a posting spec involves two account symbols posted in different currencies—one is in payment currency and the other is in position currency, then the account 22549000 will be automatically involved.

For example, the posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1902- (which is capitalized charges). 11100 debits with account symbol 1 (posting in position currency) and credits with account symbol 3 (posting in payment currency).

Now assume the position currency of the transaction if USD (the principal and interest are paid in USD), however, the charge MM1902- is paid in EUR. Check the posting log for MM1902-:

MM1902- credits bank clearing account in the transaction currency EUR (=payment currency of this flow), but its debit side recognizes position which is posted in transaction currency USD (=position currency of this transaction). In this case, two accounting documents are created for MM1902-:

  • One uses transaction currency USD, debits position account and credits technical clearing account 22549000;
  • The other uses the transaction currency EUR, debits technical clearing account 22549000 and credits bank clearing account.

The technical clearing account 22549000 is involved in two documents, and it has identical amounts in valuation currency within two accounting documents.

This kind of handling is necessary because only one single transaction currency is allowed in one accounting document (design of FI).

entry.title: Need to know how can Return Revenue GL can be assigned Different Return Revenue GL
entry.content:
Dear Community,

Our requirement is to set the different revenue GL for return processing for credit memo. In this case, how can we achieve this requirement through standard behavior? If this can't be achieved in a standard way, then how could we achieve this? 

Need to Assign for Return Order (CBAR or CBRE) for Credit Memo.


--- Steps to Reproduce ---

1. Create a return order type through CBAR/CBRE, where we will use the reference document as an invoice document. 

2. Create Outbound Delivery and PGR 

3. Create Credit Memo (Accounting Impacted: the Revenue GL for Return is Debit, and the Reconciliation Account for Customer would be Credit).

Thank you for your inputs!

entry.title: Quality level is not resetting back from Skip to Normal as per DMR in SAP QM
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

Good day, 

I have situation where I am maintaining Dynamic Modification Rule (DMR) with 2 stages as per client requirement. Requirement is to have only 1 inspection lot which is deliverable and next all lots should be skipped for the day. So, I have configured state 10 with Normal inspection and if it is UD accepted than inspection will move to state 20 as skip lot state and rest period is 1 day and also max allowed period is 1 days for state 20 (skip lot).

entry.title: Re: ME21N Retention fields – which CDS view contains them?
entry.content:
Hi,

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Retention field you see in Create Purchase Order – Advanced is UI-only.

  • The field is not currently exposed

  • It is not part of the Purchase Order API

  • It is not extensible via: Custom fields (key-user extensibility), CDS view extensions or Badi.

Retention cannot be passed via the Purchase Order API in S/4HANA Public Cloud currently.

Since this is a system limitation, please log a customer influence request. The development team monitors these requests and if it is within the scope of implementation, this will be put on SAP Road Map Explorer.

  1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 
  2. Register and accept the Terms of Use
  3. Choose a session of your interest
  4. Create and submit your improvement request
  5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

Thanks and regards,

Krithika

Is this possible in standard SAP material ledger?
